item.description: Abraham Erally was an Indian writer of history.

item.title: John Beames: Indian Languages
item.description:
Book: John Beans, A Comparative Grammar of the Modern Aryan Languages of India, Munshiram Manoharilal, 1966, (published in Sept 1871).

An interesting perspective from a 19th century British linguist.

item.description:

item.title: Samadhi of Shivaji
item.description: Many Mumbai landmarks have been named renamed for Shivaji. It is interesting to note that his Samadhi was poorly maintained until late 19th century

item.title: Arabic and Persian in India
item.description: Some notes on the use of Persian and Arabic in India.

item.title: Hindi and Urdu
item.description: Hindi and Urdu (Hindustani/Hindvi) have the same syntax and grammar and the language shares its origin with other Indo-European languages such as Bengali, Oriya, Gujarati, Bengali, Marathi etc.

item.title: Ramdas: Brahmins, Muslims and Women
item.description: Mahipati composed Santavijaya almost a century after Samarth Ramdas’s death in 1681.

item.title: History and Narratives
item.description: Frequently historians present themselves as objective observers just using evidence to presen the history. However to me it appears that many have some framework and narrative in mind and then choose evidence to fit the story they want to tell.

item.title: Bernard Cohn on British India
item.description:
For over view see https://press.princeton.edu/books/paperback/9780691000435/colonialism-and-its-forms-of-knowledge.

Source: Colonialism and Its Forms of Knowledge: The British in India, Bernard Cohn

item.title: Trautmann: Aryans and British India
item.description:
Trautmann came across a stone inscription in Sanskrit near the entryway of the Old Indian Institute Building at Oxford. From viewing this, the special character of British concept of Aryan came to him as an epiphany. (page 3)

Aryans and British India, Thomas R. Trautmann, ISBN 0-520-20546-4, Call number DS425.T68 1997, University of California Press.

item.title: Persian in South Asia
item.description: The spread of the Persian in the subcontinent began with the conquest of Ghazni’s conquest of the Punjab. Although Persian was not the mother tongue of most of the rulers, it became the language of administration, courts, literary activity and high culture. The Indo-Persian cultural tradition began during this period.

item.title: Tantra: Hugh B. Urban
item.description: This is an example of progression from Indomania to Indophonia, under the influence of Christian and Evangelical who wanted to emancipate natives socially and culturally.

item.title: Vedic Mathematics
item.description: I wondered about what is “Vedic” about “Vedic Mathematics”.

item.title: Ali-Dashti on the Quran
item.description: Ali Dashti was born in 1896 in Dashtestan in Iran. At a young age, he was trained in Islamic theology, history, Arabic and Persian grammar, and classical literature in madrasas in Karbala and Najaf (both in Iraq).

item.title: Jinnah
item.description: Here are quotes from prominent authors on Jinnah.

item.title: Alberuni
item.description: The movements of Bīrūnī in India seem to have been modest. The word “Hindu” does not appear in Al Bīrūnī’s original Arabic text on religions of India.

item.title: Akbar
item.description: The following Dawn article published July 19, 2009 outlines the role played by historian I.H.Qureshi, S.M. Ikram in redefining history from the perspective of the two nation theory.

item.title: Punjabi in Pakistan
item.description: It is interesting to note that Abdus Salam, Nobel Prize winnner for Physics in 1979 gave his convocation address at Gurudev Nanak university of Amritsar on 25 January 1981 in rural Punjabi. He also received his Nobel Prize in traditional Punjabi attire. He needed some help in wrapping his turban around properly.
